# Cambridge International AS & A Level

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[737, 214, 907, 255]]<|/det|>  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 277, 232, 293]]<|/det|>
## MATHEMATICS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[836, 277, 907, 293]]<|/det|>
9709/22  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 312, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 2 Pure Mathematics 2  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[710, 303, 907, 319]]<|/det|>
October/November 2021  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 907, 345]]<|/det|>
1 hour 15 minutes  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>
You must answer on the question paper.  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 435, 880, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 664, 217, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[94, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 50.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>1</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 393, 92]]<|/det|>
The polynomial \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is defined by

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[411, 100, 584, 120]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{p}(x) = a x^{3} + b x - 10,\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 127, 920, 163]]<|/det|>
where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants. It is given that \((x + 2)\) is a factor of \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) and that the remainder is \(-55\) when \(\mathrm{p}(x)\) is divided by \((x + 3)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 173, 146, 191]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 173, 373, 191]]<|/det|>
Find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 174, 920, 191]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>2</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 712, 92]]<|/det|>
Sketch, on the same diagram, the graphs of \(y = x + 3\) and \(y = |2x - 1|.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 306, 148, 325]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 306, 440, 325]]<|/det|>
Solve the equation \(x + 3 = |2x - 1|\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 306, 920, 325]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 688, 186, 707]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 688, 920, 725]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(y\) such that \(5^{\frac{1}{2}y} + 3 = \left|2 \times 5^{\frac{1}{2}y} - 1\right|\). Give your answer correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 705, 920, 724]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 74, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 316, 92]]<|/det|>
The curve with equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[430, 94, 568, 112]]<|/det|>
\[y = 5x - 2\tan 2x\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 119, 581, 138]]<|/det|>
has exactly one stationary point in the interval \(0\leqslant x< \frac{1}{4}\pi .\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 149, 905, 168]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of this stationary point, giving each coordinate correct to 3 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 166, 920, 184]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 84, 94, 103]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 72, 682, 116]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\int_{a}^{a + 14} \frac{1}{3x} \mathrm{~d}x = \ln 2\), find the value of the positive constant \(a\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 84, 920, 102]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 440, 92]]<|/det|>
A curve has equation \(x^{2} + 4x \cos 3y = 6.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 106, 792, 125]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of the gradient of the normal to the curve at the point \(\left(\sqrt{2}, \frac{1}{12}\pi\right)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 106, 920, 125]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 96, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>6</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 73, 818, 92]]<|/det|>
By sketching a suitable pair of graphs on the same diagram, show that the equation

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[453, 98, 544, 117]]<|/det|>
\[\ln x = 2\mathrm{e}^{-x}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 125, 326, 144]]<|/det|>
has exactly one root.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 125, 920, 144]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 477, 148, 495]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 477, 630, 495]]<|/det|>
Verify by calculation that the root lies between 1.5 and 1.6.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 477, 920, 495]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 663, 92]]<|/det|>
Show that if a sequence of values given by the iterative formula

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[445, 100, 551, 122]]<|/det|>
\[x_{n + 1} = \mathrm{e}^{2\mathrm{e}^{-x_{n}}}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 127, 685, 146]]<|/det|>
converges, then it converges to the root of the equation in part (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 127, 920, 146]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 400, 186, 419]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 400, 920, 435]]<|/det|>
Use the iterative formula in part (c) to determine the root correct to 3 significant figures. Give the result of each iteration to 5 significant figures.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 415, 920, 434]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 99, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>7</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 591, 92]]<|/det|>
Prove that \(4\sin x\sin (x + \frac{1}{6}\pi)\equiv \sqrt{3} - \sqrt{3}\cos 2x + \sin 2x.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 73, 920, 92]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 625, 186, 644]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 621, 500, 650]]<|/det|>
Find the exact value of \(\int_{0}^{\frac{5}{6}\pi} 4 \sin x \sin (x + \frac{1}{6}\pi) \, \mathrm{d}x.\)

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 625, 920, 644]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>title<|/ref|><|det|>[[482, 45, 510, 62]]<|/det|>
